awd_titl_txt: Dimensions of Care Giving and Eldercare Technology in an Aging Society
awd_abstract_narration:
The current speed and scale of global aging is unprecedented in human history. By 2050, the proportion of those aged 65 or older within the estimated world population will be nearly 17%, doubling the ratio in 2015 and tripling the percentage back in 1975. Having so many live so long is a fundamentally new phenomenon to humankind. Consequently, we need to reevaluate the infrastructures of eldercare and healthcare. Such a reevaluation would benefit immensely from empirical studies that compare different caregiving options. This project will yield wide-ranging qualitative data by investigating the rapidly shifting landscape of eldercare choices in aging society. Specifically, it focuses on (1) non-familial caregivers while juxtaposing them with (2) the traditional familial care and (3) the emerging care technology. The main questions are: How can the care work provided by non-familial caregivers alter the boundaries of familial, sociological, and national kinship? How do different parties involved in eldercare understand the ramifications of care labor, vis-a-vis other options such as familial care and care provided through artificial intelligence? Not only will the findings of this research be important for the social scientific theories of care, they will also have broader policy implications by advancing our knowledge about the challenges facing social security in the aging world today.

The investigator will conduct the research in Japan, the country with the oldest population in the world that is projected to retain this position through at least 2050. Japan is the most appropriate site for this type of study that compares different care options because it has been experimenting with migrant caregivers and care technology ever since the rapid demographic changes destabilized the provision of familial care. For the collection of data pertaining to foreign caregivers, the methods will consist of participant observation, interviews, and demographic surveys. The investigator will conduct additional interviews with family caretakers and carry out participant observation and archival research about care technology to ensure the comparative axis of the methodology. Data analysis will employ the grounded theory approach to find out the culturally significant changes in the views about kinship and eldercare. The existing works on aging and care tend to study different care options separately, in particular familial care and paid care. This study contributes to the anthropological theories of eldercare and kinship by adopting a comparative approach that probes how foreign care workers fare in relation to family caregivers and technological automation of care. The holistic approach to the shifting landscape of eldercare can address the topical and analytical limitations of the current scholarship. Moreover, due to the prominent trend of global population aging today, the findings from the pioneering aging of context of Japan can be extrapolated to countless other countries that face similar demographic challenges, importantly the United States.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to produce wide-ranging qualitative data about rapidly evolving eldercare options in an aging society. To this end, the PI conducted an extensive empirical fieldwork in Japan—the country currently with the oldest population in the world—by employing semi-structured interviews, observational site visits, participant observation, and archival research. The research sites were diverse, ranging from a non-profit group that supports family caregivers, to a caregiver school that trains foreign migrants, to an eldercare facility that deploys more than 30 “care robots.” In the anthropological literature on caregiving, migrant caregivers, family caregivers, and technological automation of care tend to be studied separately. By juxtaposing these three care options, the PI analyzed the changes and tensions that impact the societal attitudes toward eldercare infrastructure and thereby contributed to the scholarly field.

A preliminary analysis of findings shows three main trends.

First, the most promising function of “care robots” is to automate and streamline caregiving tasks via indirect assistance, rather than to replace human labor that involves direct contact with elders. In Japan, “care robots” are officially defined as “mechanic systems that detect, assess, and operate in response to information” that also “bolster the user’s autonomy or lessen the caregiver’s burden.” Contrary to the popular image that “robots” possess motor systems or humanoid features, “care robots” under such a definition can encompass a far wider variety of devices—for example, a sensor mat placed under a mattress that can detect elders’ sleep quality and alert caregivers to potential signs of nighttime wandering. For the English-speaking audience, therefore, what are called “care robots” in Japan may translate better as “care technologies.” Among the most promising care technologies today are monitoring devices (e.g. cameras, sensors, mini-microphones) and care task management software (e.g. digitization, visualization, and data storage of activities and vital signs), especially because they are conducive to the “productive and scientific care” promoted by the government. As a result, care technologies at the current phase are more about the digitization and automation of care tasks and only to a lesser degree about the mechanization of tactile or emotional care. Although many parties acknowledged the necessity of “higher productivity” in eldercare given the staff shortage, cautious voices were also heard especially regarding the privacy concerns raised by some technologies.

Second, although the aging of family caregivers—along with the care recipients themselves—increases the demand for technologies suitable home-based care, many products with relative success on the current market remain better suited for institutional care. Even with the public subsidies and insurance coverage, new care technologies often come with price tags prohibitive for individual consumers. Many caregiving machines—such as transfer lifts from a bed to a wheelchair—are simply too large for residential spaces, too. The technologies that have proven beneficial to streamline care in an institutional setting do not straightforwardly benefit family caregivers the same way, as they have just one or two elders to take care of, instead of dozens or hundreds. As a result, most family caregivers have not yet felt a significant benefit from the recent technological inventions. They more often expressed the desire for societal and bureaucratic changes, such as better access to affordable non-institutional care. Thus, the attempts at technological solutions for the care shortage did not always align with other visions for the better future based on welfare reforms.

Third, the growing reliance on temporary migrants in the eldercare sector may negatively impact the quality of care elders receive. Although the nation’s front door remains mostly shut to prospective immigrants, diverse groups of foreigners have been settling in Japan by resorting to little-advertised legal pathways based on educational credentials or kinship ties. As a result, a large number of Filipina marriage migrants, Japanese-Filipinos, and their offspring live in the country today, long constituting the largest foreign group in the medicine and welfare workforce. Recently, however, the legalization of “technical trainee” visas for migrant caregivers has triggered an influx of short-term guest workers into the eldercare industry. These visas for foreign caregivers do not convert to long-term or permanent visas, and thus all but a select few are bound to leave the country after a temporary stay. The ongoing shift from virtual immigrants to temporary guest workers is reshaping the collective quality of care they provide, sometimes to the worse, as the latter group are not granted the time nor the lifestyle conducive to the long-term development of pertinent socio-linguistic skills. In the context of the intensifying global competition for care labor, the normalization of temporary workers such as “technical trainees” offers a cautionary tale.

The funded research has thus far yielded conference proceedings and journal articles under review. The PI is working on more peer-reviewed articles in addition to a monograph tentatively titled “Who Cares? Stories of Caregiving in the Aging World.”
